Price elasticity along a straight line

If you calculate the midpoint elasticity when the price declines from R8 to R7 you will obtain an elasticity of 5 (relatively elastic). In this high price range and low quantity range, the percentage change in price is low because the starting value is high (R8 to R7), while the percentage in quantity is low because the starting value is low (10 to 20).

Calculating the midpoint elasticity for a change in price from R5 to R4 will give you a price elasticity of 1 (unitary elasticity).

For a change in price from R2 to R1, you will obtain a price elasticity of 0,20 (relatively inelastic). In this low price range and high quantity range, the percentage change in price is high since the starting value for the price is low (R2 to R1), while the percentage in quantity is high because the starting value for the quantity (70 to 80) is high.

Examine the data, not the graph, to decide whether demand is relatively inelastic, unitary elastic or relatively elastic.
